11:05 am
PM

Paul Volcker I was at Harvard and they give you an MA when you pass your general examination for the PhD, and I went off to London to write the thesis. But I got lazy and found other things to do than writing a thesis in 1952, or whenever it was.

So I didn’t get around to writing it. I went back and got a job. I wasn’t intending to become a professor anyway. In those days, the idea of getting a PhD actually was not as common and was not considered de rigueur the way it is today.

Cardiff Garcia You returned to New York.

Paul Volcker Well, I had a good time, I learned a lot in London, I got around Europe, I ran into a girlfriend.

Cardiff Garcia You got distracted by a girlfriend in Europe?

Paul Volcker I got distracted and it probably helped me. So I don’t think I really wasted my time, but sometimes I think maybe I should’ve gone back and done something. I had a good thesis topic, I must say, but it’s irrelevant now.

Cardiff Garcia Oh, what was it? I’m curious.

Paul Volcker In those days, it would’ve been on monetary policy, but the difference in monetary policy in central banking between the US, which had a very diversified banking system, 14,000 banks, and what’s going on in the UK, which in those days only had 4 or 5 banks that made a difference. They had four big banks and two big banks by our size. But they didn’t have a lot of little banks.

And would that make a difference in operating monetary policy and how you did it and the effectiveness. Anyway, I never did it.

PM

Excellent stuff. Well worth your time -- I promise

11:11 am
BE

Want Berenberg here? I'll share some Berenberg. They can find something to say about it.

BE

● This morning Bayer published details of a $62bn all-cash offer to acquire Monsanto –
equivalent to an offer price of $122 per share. Critically, the offer will be supported by an
equity rights issue of 25% of the deal value. This is a lower equity component than we had
envisioned and helps make the deal accretive.
● Bayer has also said it expects to realise $1.5bn of deal synergies, fully implemented after
three years. The company expects the deal to be accretive to core EPS by mid-single digits in
its first full year and double-digits accretion thereafter.
● The company believes the deal will be possible without any disposals (eg of Animal Health).
We have updated our merger model to reflect this morning’s announcement. We find the
deal to be up to 11% accretive by 2020.

BE

● However, there are several unresolved issues. Will Monsanto accept an offer at this level? We
think it will seek a higher offer, but much will depend on whether the process becomes
competitive, for instance if BASF get involved. Is the synergy target realistic? We think $1.5bn
of savings is very ambitious, although Bayer has a good track record on cost synergies in
prior deals. Its track record in sales synergies is not as robust (eg with Merck OTC) and this
element of the $1.5bn target (as yet unquantified) may be viewed with scepticism.
● Most importantly, in our opinion, is the risk that a deal of this size compromises its ability to
strengthen the healthcare part of the business. Bayer needs to rebuild its phase III pipeline
and recent newsflow has been very disappointing. While there is no urgency yet, Bayer may
miss potential opportunities due to lack of financial muscle post-Monsanto.
● In summary, this deal makes strong strategic sense for the crop part of the business but
raises questions about Bayer’s ability to adequately support the pharmaceuticals business.
Furthermore, although the deal looks accretive on these terms, the accretion swiftly erodes if
Bayer needs to raise its offer (particularly if that requires a larger equity component)

11:13 am
BE

And Jefferies, with a broader waffle around the theme, pre today's update.

BE

Bayer's interest in MON appears to be confounded by its inability to construct
a clean transaction that works for both sets of shareholders. We would expect
a transaction to be destructive to near term earnings, given the disposals likely
required to achieve it. Alternative structures involving a JV offer a potential way
forward, but requires the cooperation of MON, which may not be forthcoming,
and likely an even higher price.
No doubt on strategic intent: With an approach already made towards Monsanto
(MON, $101.52, Hold) and consistent commentary from management that they want to
build the seeds business, there is no doubting Bayer's strategic intent. Management have
previously talked to bolt-on acquisitions to fill the gaps in its seeds portfolio, as well as its
own internal R&D, which would take many years to mature. Monsanto offers a rapid route to
build what management desires in seeds, but at a cost that shareholders may not approve of.
Balance sheet constrains classical debt-driven M&A in our view: Whilst a straight
cash/ debt driven deal would likely be most desirable for all parties involved, we think this is
unlikely. In addition, a cash/ debt driven acquisition would also likely be the most accretive
for Bayer. Any acquisition will likely require a significant premium to Monsanto's current
$42bn market valuation as well as taking on a further $5.7bn of its net debt. However,
Bayer's balance sheet is already stretched with combined net debt and pension liabilities of c
€30bn as of Q1'16. Bayer aims to maintain its debt rating at 'A' (it is currently 'A-'), although
management have previously acknowledged they would be willing to temporarily sit on a
lower rating for the right deal.

BE

Disposals could both help and hinder a deal to get done: Bayer still holds a c64%
stake in Covestro, which at current levels is worth c€4.7bn or c$5.3bn. We have also
previously highlighted Bayer Animal Health's (BAH) value could be monetized via a potential
'spin-version' with Zoetis (ZTS, $47.06, Buy), or straight sale to another player. Bayer recently
started reporting separate financials for Animal Health, which we see as a prelude to a
potential separation and likely because management knew it was going to need to monetize
it in the scenario of a successful bid for Monsanto. Peer group sales multiples (4.9x) based on
2017E estimates, values BAH at c€8.4bn ($9.5bn). After discussion with our Chemicals team,
we estimate that Bayer could dispose of Monsanto's Agrochemicals assets and c28% of the
more minor seeds business to potentially realize a further c€21bn ($23.7bn) of proceeds.
All in, disposals (including the Bayer assets) equating to c72% of acquired EBITDA from
Monsanto, could realize c€34bn ($38.4bn), leaving Bayer to find the remaining c€8.2bn
($9.3bn) to fund the current EV, plus whatever premium is required in order to end up with
just the major seeds business. Whilst all this may facilitate a transaction, it would likely be
time consuming to fully effect and very destructive to earnings on a near term basis. This
may not justify the longer term strategic benefits to the CropScience division in the eyes of
many shareholders and management may have to vigorously argue that Monsanto's seeds
business may be the the only effective route to meet their long term strategic goals.
Partial JV could make it work, but difficult and undesirable: We note the possibility
for a Joint Venture with Monsanto, which could facilitate the acquisition over time on a more
acceptable basis for Bayer shareholders. However, this would still likely require divestments
on both sides as well as the cooperation from Monsanto management and a higher price.
Bayer management may be open to a majority stake, but not a 50:50 venture based on their
prior comments. A JV seems one of the more affordable options in the near term, but likely
least desirable and most expensive in the long term.
Reiterate Hold rating; Best to watch and wait: Bayer looks cheap at the current
valuation and many may be tempted to risk buying, hoping the deal and the discount go
away. However, the relatively limited upside and further downside risk is unattractive to us
and we much prefer Novartis within European Large Cap Pharma.

11:14 am
BE

Caz too? Sure. Why not.

BE

This morning Bayer published details of their offer for Monsanto, which was for $122 per share equating to a
$62.2bn Enterprise Value for Monsanto (lower than the $135 we had previously used in our analysis). As well
as the offer, Bayer highlighted $1.5bn in synergies from the combination which they expected to be realised by
year 3 (this is about $500m higher than we had previously assumed). Finally at this level they capped out the
amount of equity at 25% of the deal value or around €15bn (which is around 1/2 the equity we had previously
assumed). Putting all these elements together and assuming no forced sale of Covestro and/or Animal Health we
do find the transaction 8% accretive in 2017 and 20% accretive by 2019. With the ROIC in 2019 also 8.1% and
this accretion the transaction will look somewhat more palatable to investors although 4x Net debt /EBITDA
will cause some concerns. However, we believe it is unlikely that the deal gets done at $122 and still believe
$135 is a more likely price. At this price with the rest of the purchase financed in Equity the accretion is reduced
to 1.8% in 2017 and 12.9% in 2019 and would be further reduced with a sale of Covestro by 5% or so. Overall it
is now clear that Bayer is unlikely to back away from this transaction even though they will probably have to
pay more, hence Investors will have to adjust to the reality of 50:50 Heathcare:Crop Science company which is
stretching Bayer's balance sheet – if the deal is completed. While the strategic rationale from a Crop Science
point of view remains clear, dilution of Healthcare will continue to disappoint some investors, therefore while
Bayer's standalone shares are trading substantially below our last published Sum of the parts at €118, we do not
expect a recovery in the near-term.

BE

Though, really, I'd rather put a gif up of Bill Murray dropping a toaster into the bath. But we're the FT. We're not allowed to do that.

The UK Treasury’s latest calculations on the immediate cost of leaving the European Union are out. Among the key points, the number crunchers conclude the following:

Britian “would enter recession” lasting a year in event of an exit from the EU
500,000 UK jobs would be lost
GDP “would be around 3.6 per cent lower”
In a “severe shock scenario”, GDP would be 6 per cent lower and 800,000 jobs would be lost.
“In contrast, a vote to remain in the EU would see current uncertainty fall back rapidly with little lasting impact on the economy.”

11:25 am
BE

As in mobile versus fixed transmitters. If you're unsure on the tech it's a good read.

BE

Nevertheless, ships are getting broken up into bits and that's bad.

BE

Downgrade to Equal-weight: Despite a 33% YTD decline in the shares
(offsetting +42% in 2015), we see: (1) 2018 revenue guidance as too
ambitious. Management has already cut 2016 revenue guidance by 4%, but
kept 2018 targets, and we expect these to be the next to fall away; and (2)
Scope for earnings downgrades. We cut 2017-18 EPS forecasts by 18-22%.
Cutting estimates below guidance and consensus: Inmarsat targets
revenue growth of 2% in 2016, but sees acceleration to 11-13% CAGR for
2017 and 2018. We think this looks too ambitious given pressure in the data
business, with Eutelsat citing "slowing industry-wide growth". The revenue
uplift for Inmarsat relies on Global Xpress, predominantly in the maritime and
government markets. In Maritime, in particular, we see 2 headwinds: (1)
Recession in the global maritime market resulting in vessels being laid up
or scrapped; (2) Increased competition in new growth markets, such as for
cruise liners and oil & gas rigs (see O3b's contract with Royal Caribbean). We
still look for 8% mid-term revenue growth, but sit 8% below the mid-point of
the 2018 revenue target.

11:26 am
BE

PT cut to 800p driven by lower estimates and terminal growth. We think the
market values the core satellite business at a P/E of 18x for 2017 and 16x for
2018 (considering 200p in value for Ligado Networks - formerly
LightSquared). FSS peers trade on 15x 2018 earnings. We acknowledge that
the Inmarsat multiple could come under pressure if further negative industry
news were to materialise given the high expected growth built into forecasts
(MSe +8% revenues, +21% EPS over 2016-18 CAGR).

BE

What could go right: (1) New airline deals would be supportive. Indeed,
the last agreement was in Nov 15 with Singapore Airlines for GX, and
management says talks with other airlines are ongoing. (2) Launch of the 4th
GX satellite is due in the latter part of 2016 and management will provide an
update on guidance closer to the launch date. We assume $40mn of revenues
in 2017, ramping up to $60mn in 2018 before reaching its steady run-rate of
$100mn by 2019. (3) New acquisitions – management has not commented
on the potential for new deals, but we note that M&A has been a strategy to
boost growth in the past (eg, purchase of ShipEquip in 2011).

BE

I've spun through all 23 pages this morning and it's one of the most reluctant downgrades I remember seeing.

11:28 am
PM

But the stocks off close to 4%, nevertheless

BE

Inmarsat - unique investment highlights vs other EU listed satellite peers
Inmarsat has a revenue stream from Ligado Networks (formely LightSquared) with
the revenue stream now guaranteed for the next 3 years vs previous uncertainty as
Ligado was in Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
On top, Inmarsat has a unique opportunity in the European aviation market, where it
is working with DT to develop an air-to-ground network to deliver WiFi onboard
planes.
Inmarsat's competitive selling point is that it offers global satellite coverage.
Normally, satellite operators face a trade off between speed vs coverage.
This is particularly important in maritime for ships travelling from one continent to
another.
Inmarsat offers the best of both, with its L-band service guarding against rain fade, but
Ka-band delivering speeds of 50 Mbps.

BE

Loads of that kind of thing. It's a "best house in a bad neighbourhood" kind of argument, I guess.

PM

Here's a bit of Credit Suisse

PM

Downgrade to Neutral: Following FY16 results, we downgrade our rating to Neutral (from Outperform) reflecting weak
electronic volumes and lower NewCo (NEX) earnings estimates resulting from higher retained costs. We continue to model
for the whole of ICAP plc, including the businesses being sold, and cut our FY17-18 EPS estimates 5-8% on lower
electronic volume growth and higher cost assumptions. Our price target falls to 450p (from 475p), in line with our revised
forecasts.
 Lacking earnings momentum: ICAP reported weak FY16 results with trading PBT down 11% yoy reflecting poor volumes
and ongoing investment. ICAP's electronic volumes are off to a subdued start to the new financial year and the company
has warned that the path to more normal market conditions is likely to be "long and slow". Consensus forward EPS
estimates have fallen c.10% YTD but the risks still look skewed to the downside in our view.

PM

Fundamental valuation looks up with events: ICAP disclosed FY16 PAT from continuing earnings of £86m, or £105m
including estimated dividend income from the enlarged Tullett Prebon group (TP-ICAP). This is lower than our prior forecast
of £120m, reflecting £14m of group costs which will not transfer to TP-ICAP. We assume the NEX cost base is optimised
over time, but trading on a P/E of over 17x our CY17E, valuation is now in line with the global diversified exchanges which
we think implies limited upside potential.
 Material upside potential in a theoretical takeout scenario: NEX will own some strategic pieces of OTC market infrastructure
which we think are likely to be worth more to an exchange given scope for synergies. While we see material upside in a
theoretical takeover scenario, we do not believe management plan to sell while we think the probability of a takeover
approach has receded as the most likely acquirers await the fallout from the proposed merger of LSE and DB1.

11:33 am
BE

Levine was characteristically excellent last week on the theme of Icap's new name, incidentally.

BE

The basic facts are that "ICAP, the interdealer broker, will rebrand itself as NEX Group once the sale of global broking business to rival Tullett Prebon is completed" and it becomes "a largely electronic trading and markets infrastructure business." But the real meat of the story is this:

ICAP chose the name and new black and white logo after sifting through more than 300 suggestions. It even ran a competition open to the public, offering a case of vintage wine to the winner. The preferred idea from BlackRock employee Mark Johnson, “Quantum”, ran into copyright problems but ICAP still awarded him a case of 1990 Château Latour.

Okay, one, is it possible to imagine a more generic financial-services-whatever name than "Quantum"? Except maybe "NEX"? Or "ICAP"? (Formerly "Intercapital"?) These names are ... I don't want to say that they're bad, exactly, but if I had known that you could get a case of 1990 Latour just for telling a financial company to rename itself "Quantum," I'd be expensively drunk all the time.

BE

And, two, is there a more interdealer-broker move than buying someone a case of Bordeaux in exchange for a service? Remember when ICAP was fined $88 million for helping to manipulate Libor, in part based on an e-mail from an ICAP employee to Tom Hayes allegedly suggesting that "an annual champagne shipment, a few piss ups with Danny and a small bonus every now and then" were sufficient compensation for Libor rigging? You might think that the currency of money dealers would be money, but apparently it's fancy wine.

Further to the announcement on 10 July 2015, the Company has been advised that, despite much effort by Mr Stoller, the expected transfer of 901,615 ordinary shares in the Company to David Stoller (Executive Chairman) has not taken place as expected due to the inability of the other party to comply with the settlement agreement entered into at the time. The parties have now agreed that a cash payment will be made to Mr Stoller instead and Mr Stoller has indicated to the Company that he intends to invest this in purchasing existing ordinary shares in r4e when he is able to and the Company is not in a close period. Accordingly, David Stoller's beneficial interest in ordinary shares in the Company is currently 23,927,358 shares, representing approximately 4.99 per cent. of the issued share capital.

PM

r4e, the transatlantic media and entertainment marketing company announces, in accordance with Rule 17 and Schedule Two (g) of the AIM Rules for Companies, that it has been notified of the following information by Marcus Yeoman:

A receiver was appointed to Powamatique Limited on 25 June 2009, while Mr Yeoman was acting as a director of the company. The receiver was appointed on behalf of a bank in order to recover a commercial property asset over which it held a charge. Mr Yeoman ceased to act as a director of Powamatique Limited on 5 July 2011 and the company was ultimately dissolved via a compulsory strike off on 17 July 2012.

PM

It was announced on 13 November 2015 that the Board recognised the importance of retaining and incentivising employees and therefore agreed to put in place a share incentive scheme and to make grants under the scheme of up to 20 per cent. of the issued share capital at an exercise price of 1p per share, being the price of the placing announced on that date. Accordingly, under the Scheme, options over a total of 84,475,000 new ordinary shares in the Company, representing approximately 17.75 per cent. of the current issued ordinary share capital of the Company, have today been granted to employees and senior management, including to the Executive Chairman and Acting CEO (the "Options"). Of the total Options granted, 23,750,000 were granted to David Stoller, the Executive Chairman and Acting CEO of the Company, which represent approximately 4.99 per cent. of the current issued ordinary share capital of the Company.

11:42 am
PM

Oh and this from circa 16 years ago....

PM

A bullying letter has arrived in this office from Kingsley Napley, the lawyers, who say they have been `consulted' by the Colombus Group,a small publishing firm, over an article in these pages referring to the dealings of Nigel Wray, who until last week was deputy chairman of Colombus.

The letter accuses us of `materially' misquoting from a report by accountants KPMG and alleges a number of factual inaccuracies in our reporting. `It is abundantly clear that you have been cavalier, to say the least, in the way in which you have reported the matter,' the letter states, before going on to demand all manner of undertakings from this newspaper.

Well, providing anything of the sort is going to be a little difficult since Kingsley Napley's charges are entirely misdirected. The article complained of - a piece on the reverse takeover of shell company Knutsford, where Mr Wray is also on the board - made no mention of Colombus or, indeed, Mr Wray's dealings. What is more, KPMG's `confidential document' has not been written about or quoted from in any form. Until now, that is.

For the bemused it should be explained that KPMG is reported to have carried out a forensic audit at Colombus (which is being taken over by another publisher Highbury House) following three separate raids on the company by officials from the Department of Trade last year. No action followed the raids, but a series of articles recently appeared in the Times focusing on a big sale of shares by Mr Wray a few weeks before a profits warning by Colombus and also while the DTI probe was still under way.

Mr Wray has protested that he did not know about the DTI's concerns and certainly knew nothing about the impending profits warning when he sold his stock. There is no reason to doubt the man's word. But, given Kingsley Napley's nudge, this is probably as good a chance as any to warn that, on past experience, any regular medium-to-long term investor who sinks money into a company where Mr Wray is involved stands a good chance of losing a sizeable portion of their investment.

The financier is a leading proponent of the City's penny-stock game. Typically, Mr Wray and his associates bring a small, high-risk company to the market in a flotation pitched at a few pence per share. A group of professional investors support the issue, raising a few million pounds for the company, before selling all or most of their shares to other investors.

These new shareholders may be regular punters, attracted to penny shares because they have read a tip-sheet advertisement promising untold riches for those who dream big and buy small. Alternatively, the new shareholders may be one of a number of so-called City bucket shops - fringe stockbrokers that buy big parcels of penny stocks and then use teams of high-pressure tele-salesmen to sell the stock on at an inflated price to amateur investors.

Mr Wray's record of directorships, past and present, runs to many dozens of companies - firms such as Trocadero (now renamed Chorion), Burford, Nottingham Forest, Grantchester, Talisman, and so on. In many cases, Mr Wray's shares enjoy an initial surge, fuelled by excited publicity, only to slump once the low quality of the underlying business becomes apparent. The last mug punter in loses all the money.

There is nothing illegal about any of this. It is just how a portion of the small company community operates through the London stock market. But it is a shabby business all the same.

PM

BE

We reduce our FY16/17E underlying EBITDA by 4%/8% to £375/365 mn to
reflect a slower 2H16 sales growth trend (-3% from +2%) in the context of
the current demanding European apparel market. In addition to the lower
FY16E EBITDA base, we are concerned that the opportunity to pass
through input cost inflation (ccy driven) is now limited. Together these
themes drive lower £282/264 mn FY16/17 PBT forecasts (EPS 36.04/33.76p),
a lower PT and our downgrade to Neutral (from Buy). Since adding to the
Buy List on Feb. 17, 2012 the shares are +28.7% vs. FTSE World Europe
+13%, driven by retail execution in the UK in the early part of this period.

BE

Dunno why they insist on writing notes in the style of a particularly nervous junior lawyer who works for a council office, but there we are.

BE

Current view
EPS growth stalled across FY15-18E – We expect the combination of a
demanding European apparel demand environment, gross margin
pressure (ccy driven) and elevated opex growth due to a one-off wage bill
increase to stall Sport Direct’s EPS progress in FY16, FY17 and FY18 (EPS
now 36.04p/33.76p/35.76p), despite the European football event this
summer.

Neutral, 12-month price target decreases to 400p – Due to the impact of
the above to our earnings estimates, our 12-month price target decreases
to 400p (from 525p). This is based on 9x EV/EBIT (from 10x given the
slower earnings growth trajectory) applied to our FY17 forecasts and
equates to an 11.8x 2017E P/E, 6% FCF yield. Given the limited upside to
our price target (8%) in the context of our sector average +18%, drives our
downgrade to a Neutral rating (from Buy).

11:52 am

Key downside risks to our view and price target remain the inconsistent
European trading performance, any persistence of the current weaker
store-based LFL sales trajectory, and gross margin headwind from adverse
currency moves (£$ and €$). Key upside risks include better-than-
expected trading or cost control; potential buyout by founder.
